overview: Statutory Sick Pay is money you get when you're off work due to sickness - what you'll get, eligibility, how to claim
title: Statutory Sick Pay (SSP)

table.body:
You can get £85.85 per week Statutory Sick Pay if you're too ill to work. It's paid by your employer for up to 28 weeks. 

You need to [qualify](statutory-sick-pay#eligibility "Eligibility") for SSP and have been off work for 4 or more days in a row (including non-working days). 

You can't get less than the statutory amount. You can get more if your company has a sick pay scheme (or 'occupational scheme') - check your employment contract. 

% There are different sick pay rules for [agricultural workers](/agricultural-sick-pay "Agricultural Sick Pay"). % 

*[SSP]: Statutory Sick Pay
table.title: Overview

table.body:
You can get £85.85 a week Statutory Sick Pay (SSP) for up to 28 weeks. 

You get SSP for the days you would normally have worked. It's not paid for the first 3 days you're off, unless you've been paid SSP within the last 8 weeks and are eligible for it again. 

^ If you have more than one job you may get SSP from each employer. ^

##How you're paid

SSP is paid by your employer in the same way as your normal wages (eg weekly or monthly). 

Tax and National Insurance will be deducted. 

*[SSP]: Statutory Sick Pay
table.title: What you'll get

table.body:
To qualify for Statutory Sick Pay (SSP) you must:

- be classed as an [employee](/employment-status/employee "Employment status") and have done some work for your employer
- have been ill for at least 4 days in a row (including non-working days)
- earn at least £107 (before tax) per week
- tell your employer you're sick before their deadline - or within 7 days if they don't have one

^ Agency workers are entitled to Statutory Sick Pay. ^

##Fit notes (or sick notes) 

You only have to give your employer a doctor's [fit note](/fit-note-statement-fitness-to-work "Fit notes")  if you miss more than 7 days of work. 

##Exceptions

You won't qualify if you:

- have received the maximum amount of SSP (28 weeks)
- have taken 3 years or more ‘linked periods’ of sickness - where 4 or more days of sickness happen within 8 weeks of each other
- are getting statutory maternity, paternity, adoption or additional paternity pay

##If you're not eligible

If you don't qualify for SSP, your employer must give you form SSP1 within 7 days of your illness. 

You can use this to apply for [Employment and Support Allowance (ESA)](/employment-support-allowance "Employment and Support Allowance") instead. 

$D[Download 'Statutory Sick Pay form SSP1', (PDF, 205KB)'](http://www.dwp.gov.uk/advisers/claimforms/ssp1_print.pdf "Download 'Statutory Sick Pay form SSP1 (PDF, 205KB)'"){:rel="external"}$D

*[SSP]: Statutory Sick Pay
*[ESA]: Employment Support Allowance
table.title: Eligibility

table.body:
To claim Statutory Sick Pay (SSP), tell your employer in writing (if they request it) and by their deadline (or within 7 days if they don't have one).

^ You only need a doctor's '[fit note](/fit-note-statement-fitness-to-work "Fit notes")' (or sick note) if you're off sick for 7 days or more. ^  

*[SSP]: Statutory Sick Pay
